indicator.indicator-name: Marine bird population abundance: rhinoceros auklet, pigeon guillmot, marbled murrelet and scoters.
indicator.progress-icon-tagline: The results for this indicator are mixed.
indicator.progress-description: Species in the marine bird indicator are not all displaying the same pattern in abundance.~SL The marbled murrelet population, a species listed as federally threatened, has declined by nearly five percent per year over the past 16 years.~B In contrast, the density estimates of pigeon guillemot and rhinoceros auklet have gone up and down year-to-year, but show no trend over the past 16 years. ~B Sound-wide trends for pigeon guillemot are consistent with local-scale monitoring results and suggest a stable and healthy guillemot population in the Puget Sound region. ~B Studies suggest that conservation of suitable nesting habitat is key to murrelet recovery. Marine factors related to prey abundance may also play a role in murrelet distribution and trend.~EL
indicator.what: The indicator is the abundance of marine bird populations.~P The marine bird population indicator measures population abundance and trends of a handful of bird species that nest or overwinter in the marine environment. The indicator includes:~P 1. Spring/summer at-sea densities of marbled murrelet, rhinoceros auklet and pigeon guillemot. These species are highly dependent on the marine environment of, and breed in, Puget Sound and Strait of Juan de Fuca.~P 2. At-sea abundance trends of scoter species that overwinter in Puget Sound and Strait of Juan de Fuca. These species are highly dependent on the marine environment of Puget Sound and the Strait of Juan de Fuca, but do not breed there. ~P The species selected for this indicator reside in Puget Sound most, if not all, of the year. The indicator provides an integrative view of the health of species that depend upon the Puget Sound for survival, in contrast to the species being indirect indicators of something like habitat quality, contaminants, or prey. ~P The Washington State Department of Fish and Wildlife conducts marine bird surveys in the spring/summer months and in January for wintering birds. The spring/summer surveys are boat-based and are part of the Northwest Forest Plan effectiveness monitoring program for the Marbled Murrelet (http://www.reo.gov/monitoring/reports/marbled-murrelet-reports-publications.shtml). During these surveys, observers also record other species detected. WDFW also conducts winter surveys from airplanes that allow us to assess abundance and trends of scoters and other over-wintering species (http://wdfw.wa.gov/publications/01135/).~P The marine bird indicator was officially endorsed by the Science Panel at their April 9, 2014 meeting. The endorsement was based on a peer-reviewed report written jointly by the Washington State Department of Fish and Wildlife and the Puget Sound Partnership. The report, titled “Marine and Terrestrial Bird Indicators for Puget Sound, (http://www.psp.wa.gov/vitalsigns/documents/Pearson%20and%20Hamel%20Bird%20Indicators%202013_Final.pdf) develops, presents, and uses a transparent process to identify and evaluate potential indicators and ultimately recommend marine bird indicators.~P The peer-review process was coordinated by the Puget Sound Partnership Science Panel in 2013. The report was finalized in April of 2014. The indicators were also endorsed by the Leadership Council in January 2014. Supplemental material to the report is linked here (Bird Indicator Supplementary material S1_2JAN13.xlsx, http://www.psp.wa.gov/vitalsigns/documents/Bird%20Indicator%20Supplementary%20material%20S1_2JAN13.xlsx).

figure-1.title: FIGURE 1. POPULATION DENSITY ESTIMATES AND TRENDS OF MARINE BIRD SPECIES IN PUGET SOUND
figure-1.caption: Dots are population estimates. Black line shows the linear trend. Grey band is the 95% confidence interval of the trend.
figure-1.source: Source: Washington Department of Fish & Wildlife

figure-2.title: Table 1. ESTIMATES OF AVERAGE ANNUAL RATE OF POPULATION CHANGE (LINEAR) FOR PUGET SOUND.
figure-2.description: Sound-wide, the density of pigeon guillemots and rhinoceros auklet has varied from year-to-year but with no overall trend over the past 16 years. In contrast, density of the marbled murrelet population has declined by nearly 5% per year over the past 16 years (95% CI = -7.7 to –2.1). The population size of marbled murrelets in Puget Sound and the Strait of Juan de Fuca in 2016 was estimated at 4,614 birds (95% confidence interval = 2,298 – 7,570 birds).

figure-3.title: FIGURE 2: RHINOCEROS AUKLET BURROW OCCUPANCY, HATCHING AND FLEDGING SUCCESS 2016 COMPARED TO THE 2006-2015 MEAN (±SD) ON PROTECTION ISLAND
figure-3.caption: NONE
figure-3.source: Source: Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife & University of Puget Sound
figure-3.description: Pigeon guillemot~P Pigeon guillemots nest in crevices among boulders, under driftwood, or in man-made structures such as a wharf or pipe, or even on cliff faces. Ongoing citizen-science monitoring by local Whidbey Island residents from 2008 through 2016 [Provide link: http://pigeonguillemot.org/ ] and South Sound residents [Provide link: http://www.nisquallyestuary.org/research.html] indicates stable local populations. Local population results are consistent with the sound-wide trends in density trends obtained during the spring/summer boat-based surveys.~P The number of adult guillemots in the colonies nesting in the bluffs of Whidbey Island averaged 1,032 ± 33 birds. Occupied burrows, indicated by adults going into the burrow, averaged 244 ± 20 burrows. Burrows with chicks, indicated by prey delivery to the burrow, averaged 160 ± 12. These population and reproductive measures, like the sound-wide monitoring results above, suggest a stable and healthy guillemot population in the Puget Sound region.

figure-4.title: FIGURE 3: COUNTS OF ADULTS, OCCUPIED BURROWS AND BURROWS WITH CHICKS 2016 COMPARED TO THE 2008-2015 MEAN (±SD) ON WHIDBEY ISLAND
figure-4.caption: NONE
figure-4.description: Scoters~P Three scoter species (surf, black and white-winged) over-winter in the Salish Sea. They spend about eight months of the year, with some non-breeding individuals here year-round. They are foraging, replacing their feathers and putting on weight needed to successfully reproduce in high arctic lakes in the summer. Recently published research by Vilchis et al. (2015) [Provide link: http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/cobi.12378/abstract] indicates that over-wintering species were three times more likely to exhibit population declines in the Salish Sea than local breeders; for scoter, between 1994 and 2010, they declined in 9% of the 67 depth/basin strata evaluted. In general, Vilchis et al (2015) found that alcids (species like the marbled murrelet and common murre) and sea ducks (species like the scoters) dominated the over-wintering bird community during the 1990s, whereas non-diving bird species and diving species with diverse diets dominated the wintering bird community in the 2000s.

indicator.target: There are no targets for this Vital Sign.
indicator.interim-target: There currently are no interim targets for this Vital Sign.
